awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Integrating Molecular and Material Evolution of Spider Aqueous Glues
awd_abstract_narration:
The spectacular diversity of spiders and their role as key predators across the globe can largely be attributed to their innovative uses of silk. For instance, a golden orb-web spider or a black widow can spin six different types of dry fibers and a wet adhesive silk. The wet adhesive silks made by these spiders and their relatives (the megadiverse superfamily Araneoidea) afford them greater prey retention for a lower material cost than the dry prey capture silk spun by other spider groups. Furthermore, these silk glues achieve adhesiveness in a wide variety of environments, including extreme humidity conditions that challenge commercial glues. A multidisciplinary team from three institutions will investigate how variation in adhesive protein components relates to variation in the glue's material properties. The wet adhesive silks of the 18 target species have significant variation in adhesiveness, material efficiency, and response to humidity. Thus, the discovery of constituent proteins will allow design of environmentally friendly glues with tailored properties. Furthermore, web-building spiders offer many opportunities for science educators to integrate biology, chemistry, physics, and mathematics as they engage their students in the natural world. The team of investigators will mentor undergraduate and Master's students, as well as incorporate the research into undergraduate course curricula. Additionally, team members will offer science enrichment activities at rural Virginia public elementary schools, run workshops for middle and high school science teachers, and mentor New York City high school students to complete original research projects.


The evolutionary diversity of spider aqueous glues offers a unique opportunity compared to other bioadhesives to determine how molecular building blocks contribute to different aspects of adhesion. By integrating transcriptomics, proteomics, and biomechanics within a phylogenetic framework, the proposed experiments will pinpoint protein characteristics that co-evolve with interfacial adhesion, intra-glue cohesion, and humidity responsiveness. Objective 1 identifies shifts in gene expression associated with the evolution of wet adhesive silk by profiling transcriptional diversity in each of the silk gland types of 5 divergent araneoid species and 3 outgroup taxa. It also investigates evolution of expression levels in the adhesive-producing silk glands of an additional 13 species that build different web types and forage under divergent humidity levels. Objective 2 identifies and quantitates the proteins that compose adhesive silks of all 18 species, as well as their post-translational modifications. Objective 3 measures wet adhesive silk material properties for the same 18 species at different humidities. These integrated experiments will contribute to understanding the origin and molecular underpinnings of a key innovation. Specifically, they will determine the degree to which gene expression shifts and new genes were required to make a novel type of silk. The proposed work will track evolutionary rates in glue protein characteristics, including post-translational modifications, which is currently poorly understood. Finally, glue material property measurements will test the hypothesis that humidity responsiveness of spider glue droplets has evolved for optimal performance at the humidity in which a spider species typically forages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Spiders are well-known for capturing prey with complex webs constructed from different types of silk. There are substantial differences among spiders in web design and architecture but the origin of the orb-web, a wagon-wheel structure in which the spider sits at the center, represents a key evolutionary innovation that facilitated widespread species diversification. Orb-webs need to absorb the energy of rapidly flying prey without breaking or catapulting insects back into the air and some have evolved a form of liquid silk that functions as an adhesive to keep prey stuck to the web. This biological glue coats the web capture threads and affords greater prey retention at a much lower material cost than the dry, mechanically sticky silk fibers used in more ancestral orb-webs. In addition, the extensive diversity of glue and capture fiber properties found across spider species suggests they have continued to evolve adaptively. This collaborative project took a comparative approach to identify several core components of capture web performance, focusing in particular on the genetic basis of liquid and fiber silk evolution.

Through this project, the first studies were conducted to identify the protein components of the capture threads used in both orb-webs and cob-webs. Despite large differences in mechanical properties, even among closely related species, protein composition was relatively conserved across species. However, several novel genetic features that are likely to have functional significance were identified including 1) the presence of a previously unknown primary glue silk gene (termed aggregate spidroin 3), 2) an abundance of newly-discovered and diverse proteins that are rich in the amino acid cysteine, known to form strong molecular bonds, and 3) extensive modification of specific amino acids (threonine and serine) that increase the adhesive capabilities of the primary silk glue proteins. Furthermore, in all species tested, a large suite of genes exhibit higher levels of expression in the aggregate silk glands, which produce the aqueous glue, relative to other silk glands indicating that the aggregate glands are the most genetically distinct silk glands within spiders.

A detailed study was also conducted that focused on the diversity of structural genes that function in dragline silk which provides the primary frame of an orb-web and supports a spider when it hangs or descends from a substrate. Dragline silk fibers are composed primarily of large proteins generated from a class of genes, the major ampullate spidroins (MaSps), but understanding of the evolutionary diversification of these genes is limited. By examining MaSp evolution across several species of garden spiders in the genus Argiope, extensive divergence in copy number and sequence was documented, indicating that new silk gene copies are often created and lost within the genome and can rapidly acquire new genetic features. Some of these features, such as nearly identical, regularly spaced introns and hierarchically organized protein units, are extremely unusual for any animal gene and provide valuable clues about how dragline silk achieves its remarkable strength and extensibility.

Results from this project were reported in eight peer-reviewed publications and another four are in preparation. One postdoctoral scholar was trained and 13 high-school students were mentored. Research experiences focused on spider silk genomics were provided for 27 undergraduate students at a liberal arts institution. Numerous public presentations introduced diverse audiences to the biology of orb-web spiders and the genetics of their silk.
